Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Shifting pathways toward methane in nutrient impacted tropical and sub-tropical wetlands
Award.AbstractNarration:
Freshwater wetlands are the largest single source of methane to the atmosphere. Methane is a potent greenhouse gas (approximately 24 times more potent than carbon dioxide), such that the pathways that control the production of methane in wetlands have global implications. Most wetlands, including the Florida Everglades, are affected by human-derived nutrient additions. The goal of this research is to determine the enhancement of methane production caused by increased nutrient inputs, particularly phosphate. Phosphate and other nutrients result in increased inputs of plant derived-organic matter, which is then fermented to an array of small molecules in anoxic wetland soils, which are eventually converted to methane. There are two main pathways by which microbes form methane. Approximately 70% of global freshwater wetland-produced methane arises from the acetate fermentation pathway and 30% comes from reduction of carbon dioxide. Preliminary data indicate that pathways for methanogenesis are affected by phosphorus runoff from adjacent agricultural lands. Guiding this work is the hypothesis that in addition to increasing organic matter production by plants, excess phosphate also results in higher rates of methane production due to two additional factors affecting these pathways: provision of additional supply of hydrogen substrate from nitrogen fixation that is unrelated to organic production; and shunting of methane production from acetate-derived methane to fermentation of acetate by an unusual group of bacteria, the syntrophic acetate oxidizers. This shunting benefits the carbon dioxide reduction pathway which has higher rates of methane production, is less sensitive to competitive electron acceptors (such as sulfate), is less sensitive to phosphate and ammonium inhibition, and is affected differently by increased temperature. Thus predictions of methane emissions based on temperate wetlands may not accurately forecast methane emissions from warmer climates. A combination of microbiological, isotopic and biogeochemical approaches will be employed to determine how these pathways are affected by nutrient pollution. Wetlands in South Florida and Panama will be examined.

An important component of this project is the education of future scientists and secondary school students in the United States and abroad. The investigators have long records of involvement in science education ranging from high schools to undergraduate, graduate and post doctoral education. High school students will be introduced to a variety of wetlands including those containing carnivorous plants. The project will aid not only in training the next generation of scientists at the University of Florida and Florida State University, but will also will involve students from Bethune-Cookman College, a small predominantly African American college, and local high schools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
On a global basis, most methane is produced either by reduction of CO2 by H2 (the hydrogenotrophic pathway), or by fermentation of acetate (the aceticlastic pathway). In our previous study, we observed that significantly more methane appeared to be produced by CO2 reduction in nutrient impacted regions of Water Conservation Area-2A (WCA-2A) of the Florida Everglades than in nutrient unimpacted regions.  The primary objectives of the current project were to confirm the difference in pathways along the nutrient gradient in WCA-2A, and to determine the mechanisms for the shift in pathway. Results obtained from WCA-2A would be compared with a contrasting peatland in Panama.

            We initially proposed two hypotheses to explain the difference in pathways: 1) that acetate may be preferentially fermented to H2 in nutrient impacted soils; or 2) that H2 produced during nitrogen fixation may provide additional H2 in nutrient impacted soils.  Working with our collaborators at Florida State University, we rejected both of these hypotheses. Using a combination of field studies and laboratory incubations, we showed that sulfate reducing prokaryotes (SRP) in the nutrient impacted soils compete with methanogens for acetate, thereby reducing the amount of acetate available for methanogenesis in those regions. Competition between SRP and methanogens for H2 was not an important factor in either nutrient impacted or non-impacted soils.  Organic matter quality may play a role in controlling the pathway.

            The numbers and phylogeny of SRP, nitrogen fixing bacteria, and methanogens were monitored at several timepoints from 1999 to 2014. In all samples collected at all times from WCA-2A, the dominant hydrogenotrophic group of methanogens (Methanomicrobiales) were similar in number to the dominant acetotrophic group (Methanosaeta). Both groups were more numerous in the nutrient enriched areas than in the unimpacted soils. Methanosaeta were higher than the hydrogenotrophs studied in a low sulfate, low phosphate region of another Water Conservation Area, WCA-3A. Sulfate concentrations in WCA-3A are much lower than in any of the WCA-2A sites, as might be expected if SRP are important competitors for acetate in nutrient impacted areas of WCA-2A. The relationship between SRP and methanogens can be complex, however, such that they may cooperate or may compete for energy.

            A key set of experiments supported the contention that SRP compete with methanogens specifically for acetate, thereby partially shifting the pathway from aceticlastic to hydrogenotrophic. Microcosms constructed with soils from the different sites were incubated with and without the molybdate, a specific inhibitor of SRP. As expected, the pathway (evaluated by stable isotopes in methane) shifted toward the aceticlastic pathway. The greatest shifts were observed in the microcosms with nutrient impacted soils, thereby providing strong evidence that methanogenic pathways are controlled by competition between SRP and methanogens for acetate.
